I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: It is hard at times for masters students to follow the PhD level discussion, but still valuable for those interested in energy economics to see what more advanced work in this field looks like.

This course is quite unlike other F&ES courses in that it is essentially a structured lecture series. As someone without a strong background in economics, I often did not understand the economic models associated with the presentations. That said, it was extremely valuable to be a part of the larger discussion on the implications of any given analysis and set of conclusions.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The course offers a broad overview of current research topics in the field of environmental economics. It offers PhD students the opportunity to present and share their work with Master's and PhD students. Although sometimes it is challenging to follow the ideas, and I feel there is definitely a greater payoff for PhD students in the course, I think it is helpful for Master's students who are trying to grasp research ideas and topics in this relatively new and interdisciplinary field.
Enjoyed the diversity of presentation topics. Also enjoyed hearing from researchers both in and outside of Yale.
It was fascinating to see the variety of projectsand methodologies.
The frequent question-asking throughout lectures was a great structure for the course.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think a greater diversity of presenters outside of the program and diversity of topics could be interesting. There was a great selection this semester and I would like to see that continued.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: This course offered a broad overview of research topics in my field and gave me a clearer vision of the type of work conducted by PhD students in this program.
In the future, I want to be doing the type of research that is presented on, so fits very well with my interests.
I was curious to learn about how economics models are developed. It was a great introduction to a variety of methodologies and concepts.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: To be exposed to new research in environmental and energy economics.
General interest.
I was interested in exposing myself to a set of discussions outside of my academic expertise.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: met my expectations
Yes, I figured some of the material would be over my head, but I learned a lot and enjoyed piecing together the presentations and discussion.
Yes, I was very satisfied with the course.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: This class is an easy way to gain some credits that serve as an incentive to learn more about the field of resource economics. Although I definitely recommend a math or econ background before taking this class, I think the topics are interesting for any student and help students better understand this field of research.
Try to read the papers in advance of the seminar if you can.
It's an interesting glimpse into the work of FES-Econ PhDs.
